flow.context: Greg Flaherty is President/CEO and Broker of Record at Penny Realty, a family-run San Diego PM company managing 500+ properties across vacation rentals (missionbeach.com) and long-term leasing (pennyrealty.com). Their vacation rental side runs a two-step turnover QC — contracted housekeepers clean, then a dedicated inspector verifies every unit — so they already feel the pain of missed issues at scale. They use Streamline as their PMS, just launched a $1M Homeowner Protection Program via RentalGuardian, and are actively hiring inspectors due to rapid growth. VP/CFO Shayne Flaherty is Greg's family; Rebekah Gonzalez is the Business Administrator and likely gatekeeper. Sam's in: both SoCal guys — Sam surfs and grew up in LA, Greg's company operates on Mission Beach, Pacific Beach, and La Jolla.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Greg — I work with a few other vacation rental managers down in San Diego on their inspection workflows. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Feet-on-the-desk energy. Slow, casual. Sound like you belong. Don't rush through your name or company.

branches.label: Yes / Maybe / Sounds familiar
No / Don't think so
I'm busy / Bad time
What's this about? / Who is this?
Gatekeeper answers instead of Greg

heard_yes.label: HEARD YES
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone in your shoes. What did you hear?
heard_yes.note: Let him talk. Whatever he says, bridge into discovery or the pain trigger. Don't correct or over-explain.

branches.label: Shares context / Engages
Vague / Not sure what he heard

heard_no.label: HEARD NO
heard_no.say: Ha — guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call —
heard_no.note: Self-deprecating humor breaks tension. This is just a bridge line — click straight through to the pain trigger. If he interrupts with pushback, go to permission fallback.

branches.label: He's listening / Go ahead
I'm not interested / I'm busy

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow or later this week?
bad_timing.note: Don't fight it. Just lock in a callback window. Be flexible on timing.

branches.label: Sure / Call back at a specific time
Don't call back / No

reschedule_locked.label: RESCHEDULE LOCKED
reschedule_locked.say: Perfect — I'll try you then. Appreciate it, Greg.
reschedule_locked.note: Write down the exact day and time immediately. Put it in your calendar. Don't pitch anything else.

whos_this.label: WHO IS THIS
whos_this.say: Yeah sorry about that — it is a cold call, I'll be upfront. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I called, and if it's not relevant you can totally hang up on me?
whos_this.note: They're suspicious but not hostile. Transparency disarms. Most people give you the 30 seconds.

branches.label: Sure / Fine, go ahead
No / I'm busy / Not interested

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION FALLBACK
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — it is a cold call, full transparency. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out, and you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit?
permission_fallback.note: This is your reset button. Honest and low-pressure. Works more often than you'd expect.

branches.label: Sure / Go ahead
No thanks / Not interested

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and this just isn't interesting?
permission_rejected.note: You're not pushing — you're diagnosing. The multiple choice makes it easy to answer. Either answer gives you something to work with.

branches.label: Bad timing / Caught me at a bad time
Not interesting / Not a fit

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: I work with another vacation rental CEO managing a couple hundred beachfront homes — pretty similar setup to yours. Contracted cleaners, then an inspector behind them checking every unit after each turnover. He told me even with that two-step process, stuff was still slipping through. Guest checks in, finds a stain on the sofa or a cracked cabinet door, leaves a review about it — and now he's got an owner calling asking what happened. At his scale it was real money — partial refunds, review hits, the occasional owner who just walks.
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE HERE. Let the pain land. Do NOT rush into the solution. This mirrors Penny Realty's exact setup — contracted housekeepers plus a dedicated inspector. If he interrupts with recognition or agreement, let him talk. When there's a natural opening, continue to the solution line.

branches.label: He reacts / Agrees / Wants to hear more
We already have a process for that
Not really a problem for us
Silence / Waiting

pain_solution.label: SOLUTION + CTA
pain_solution.say: We built an AI that analyzes the photos your inspectors are already taking during turnovers and flags damage, missing items, staging issues — without changing anyone's workflow. Would you be open to seeing what that looks like?
pain_solution.note: One sentence on the solution, then immediately ask. Don't oversell. Don't list features. Let him respond.

branches.label: Yeah / That's interesting / Tell me more
Hmm / Maybe / I'd have to think about it
We already have something for that
Not interested

pain_resonates.label: PAIN RESONATES
pain_resonates.say: Awesome — I don't want to pitch you on a cold call though. I'd rather just ask a couple questions so if we do talk further it's actually relevant to your world. Mind if I ask?
pain_resonates.note: He's warm — STOP SELLING. Shift to discovery. You're having a conversation now, not giving a pitch.

branches.label: Sure / Go ahead
Just send me something / Let's schedule

pain_lukewarm.label: PAIN — LUKEWARM
pain_lukewarm.say: Totally fair. If nothing else, I could walk you through what a couple other PM companies in San Diego are doing with their turnover photos to catch more stuff. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends.
pain_lukewarm.note: Lower the stakes. Make the meeting valuable even if he never buys. Peer intel is always interesting to operators running 500-plus units.

branches.label: Sure / I'd be open to that
Just send me something
I'm good / No thanks

discovery_ceo.label: DISCOVERY — CEO QUESTIONS
discovery_ceo.say: So with 500-plus properties across the vacation rental and long-term side — what's been your biggest operational headache heading into this summer?
discovery_ceo.note: Open-ended on purpose. Let him talk. Listen for: insurance or damage claims, growth or hiring challenges, inspector bandwidth, owner complaints, cleaning quality, tech gaps. Follow whatever thread he pulls.

branches.label: Mentions insurance / damage / claims / protection
Mentions growth / scaling / hiring
Describes their current process or workflow
Asks about RapidEye / Wants to hear more

insurance_thread.label: INSURANCE & DAMAGE THREAD
insurance_thread.say: That tracks — I actually saw you guys rolled out that Homeowner Protection Program, the million-dollar coverage thing. Smart move. One thing we keep hearing is the documentation piece is what makes or breaks those claims. When you've got AI-flagged photos from before and after each stay, timestamped and categorized, the whole dispute process gets way cleaner. That's actually a big part of what we do.
insurance_thread.note: Connect RapidEye to his existing initiative. He invested in the HPP infrastructure — RapidEye makes it work better by providing airtight documentation. Don't oversell, just show the link.

branches.label: That's interesting / Tell me more
We're handling the documentation side already
Talk to someone on my team about this

growth_thread.label: GROWTH & SCALING THREAD
growth_thread.say: Yeah — I saw you guys are actually hiring inspectors right now, which makes sense if the portfolio's growing. That's exactly where we come in. The companies we work with are growing their portfolios without having to hire inspectors at the same rate, because the AI catches most issues before a human even needs to review. It's not about replacing your inspectors — it's about each one covering way more units without stuff slipping through.
growth_thread.note: Mirror his growth ambition. Position RapidEye as a scaling lever, not a replacement tool. CEOs love efficiency math.

branches.label: That could help / Tell me more
We're good on the staffing side
You should talk to my ops team

process_thread.label: CURRENT PROCESS THREAD
process_thread.say: Got it — sounds like you guys have a pretty tight operation. Out of curiosity, when your inspector flags something after a turnover — how does that get documented and routed? Is that going into Streamline, or is it a separate system?
process_thread.note: You know they use Streamline. Asking about documentation workflow reveals gaps without you pointing them out. Listen for manual steps, group texts, spreadsheets, or 'it depends who's doing it.'

branches.label: Describes workflow / Opens up about gaps
We're pretty set / It works fine
That's more of an ops question

cta_meeting.label: ASK FOR THE MEETING
cta_meeting.say: I don't want to take any more of your time on a cold call. Would you be open to a quick 20 minutes this week or next? I can show you exactly what it looks like on an actual property — not a generic demo, something relevant to your setup.
cta_meeting.note: Be specific — '20 minutes this week or next.' Don't say 'sometime.' Make it easy to say yes. If he says yes, lock it in immediately.

branches.label: Sure / Yeah let's do it
I don't have budget right now
Just send me an email
I'm not the right person / Talk to my team
Not interested

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Perfect. I've got next Tuesday and Thursday open — does morning or afternoon work better for you? I'll shoot the invite over while we're on the phone so it doesn't get lost.
book_meeting.note: Offer TWO specific days. Get the time. Send the calendar invite IMMEDIATELY. Confirm his email — you have greg@coastalpro.com on file.

branches.label: Picks a time
Let me check and get back to you

meeting_booked.label: MEETING BOOKED
meeting_booked.say: Done — just sent it over to greg@coastalpro.com. Really appreciate you taking my call, Greg. Talk to you then.
meeting_booked.note: Confirm the email. Stop talking. Do NOT keep selling — you won. Get off the phone.

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's harder to keep a tool, let alone buy something new. Just so no one from my team cold calls you again — is it that budget for this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that anything new you try to bring in puts you through the ringer?
objection_no_budget.note: Agree FIRST — don't fight the objection. Then split it into two options. You're diagnosing, not pushing. Either answer gives you an opening for the test drive.

branches.label: Budget is locked / No room right now
Buying process is painful / Would need buy-in
Firm no / Really not in the cards

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it — I should've assumed you'd be all set, otherwise you probably would've reached out to us. Just so no one from my team bugs you again — is it that inspection quality isn't really a problem you're focused on right now, or is it more that you just hate cold calls? No wrong answer.
objection_not_interested.note: Self-deprecating humor helps. Most people laugh and open up. 'Not a problem' gives you info. 'Hate cold calls' is an opening — they're not rejecting the product.

branches.label: Not really a problem we have
I just hate cold calls / Bad timing
Really not interested / Please don't call
Hard no / Hostile

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with 500-plus properties you'd have to have something dialed in, otherwise it'd be chaos. Just curious — is it that you're fully covered and happy with how everything's working, or is it more that switching or adding anything right now would just be a headache?
objection_have_process.note: Validate their scale. Split the objection. 'Fully happy' is rare — most people have at least one frustration if you give them room to voice it.

branches.label: Happy with it / It works
Switching would be a pain / Too much going on
We really are set / Not looking
Hard no

test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
test_drive.say: Totally fair — you're probably not buying anything off a cold call today, and I respect that. But when budget does free up or you're evaluating what's next, the people who stay ahead are the ones who already know what's on their shortlist. Would you be open to just taking a look — not for right now, but so it's on your radar when the time comes?
test_drive.note: Zero pressure. You're selling a future look, not a purchase. The 'shortlist' framing works well with CEOs — they like being ahead of the curve. If he says yes, book it immediately.

branches.label: Sure / Why not
Just send me something first
Not right now / Maybe down the road

objection_send_email.label: OBJECTION — SEND ME AN EMAIL
objection_send_email.say: Totally fair. One question before I do — what would be most relevant to include so it doesn't just end up in the pile? Are you more interested in the damage-detection side, or how it plugs into your existing workflow with Streamline?
objection_send_email.note: This gets you useful intel AND shows you know their stack. Whatever he says, tailor the email. Always include a specific meeting time suggestion in the follow-up.

branches.label: Gives direction on what he wants to see
Just send whatever / Doesn't care

email_confirmed.label: EMAIL FOLLOW-UP CONFIRMED
email_confirmed.say: Got it — I'll send that over to greg@coastalpro.com today. I'll include a couple time options for next week in case you want to take a look after. Appreciate your time, Greg.
email_confirmed.note: Send within 30 minutes. Include: one paragraph on RapidEye specific to their setup (two-step QC, Streamline, 500+ units), one relevant case study or example, and two specific meeting time options. Follow up in 3 business days if no reply.

delegates_down.label: DELEGATES TO TEAM
delegates_down.say: Makes total sense — who on your team would be the right person to walk through this with? Would that be someone like Hunter or Cole on the vacation rental side, or Mario in ops?
delegates_down.note: Name-dropping his actual team members shows deep homework and makes the referral concrete. Get the name, best way to reach them, and whether Greg wants to be copied on the intro. Always say you'll mention Greg pointed you their way.

branches.label: Gives a name / Confirms one of them
I'll pass it along internally
Not sure / Let me think about who

referral_ask.label: REFERRAL ASK
referral_ask.say: Totally understand. If you're not the right person for this — who on your team typically owns the inspection process on the vacation rental side? If I can get a name, I'll put something tailored together so it actually lands and doesn't waste anyone's time.
referral_ask.note: You're asking for altitude — who owns inspections operationally. Your targets are Hunter Curtis (VR Manager — booking/pricing/automation), Cole Holderman (VR Manager — day-to-day ops on ~100 homes), or Mario Jimenez (Operations Manager — cross-portfolio QA).

branches.label: Gives a name or role
Just email me and I'll forward it
No one / Not interested in connecting you

referral_name.label: GOT THE REFERRAL
referral_name.say: Perfect — and what's the best way to reach them directly? I'll mention you pointed me their way so it's not completely out of the blue. Really appreciate the help, Greg.
referral_name.note: Get their name, direct phone or email, and best time to reach them. Write everything down. 'I'll mention Greg pointed me their way' warms the next call significantly. If he gives you Cole, note the surfer connection for Sam's opener on that call.

gatekeeper_slide.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper_slide.say: Hey — could you get me through to Greg? It's Sam.
gatekeeper_slide.note: Nothing else. No title, no company, no pitch. First names only. Sound like you belong. This might be Rebekah Gonzalez (Business Administrator) — if she gives her name, remember it for future calls.

branches.label: Puts you through to Greg
Who's calling? / What's this about?

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — ADD CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other property managers in San Diego. Would you mind letting him know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Still not pitching. Just one more layer of context. Always end with a question to stay in control. If they say he's unavailable, ask for the best time to catch him.

branches.label: Puts you through
What company? / Can I take a message?
He's not available / In a meeting

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Sure — it's Sam Parks with RapidEye. We help a couple other vacation rental companies with their inspection workflows. I sent Greg a note last week — would you mind giving him a heads up I called?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: 'Sent a note' gives Greg a reason to know you. If you haven't emailed yet, send one to greg@coastalpro.com immediately after hanging up. End with a redirect question.

branches.label: Puts you through
I'll pass the message along / He'll call you back

gatekeeper_blocked.label: GATEKEEPER — BLOCKED
gatekeeper_blocked.say: Appreciate that — would you happen to know the best time to catch him? I'll try back then.
gatekeeper_blocked.note: Get a callback window and write it down. Be gracious — gatekeepers remember who was rude. If this doesn't work, try the vacation rental line (866-522-4116) or the PM office (858-943-0277) as alternate routes. You can also try reaching Hunter Curtis or Cole Holderman directly as alternate entry points.

end_graceful.label: END — GRACEFUL EXIT
end_graceful.say: Totally understand, Greg. If anything changes, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Appreciate your time.
end_graceful.note: Don't burn the bridge. He runs 500+ properties in a market you want to own. Add him to a nurture sequence and try again in 60-90 days. Consider reaching Hunter Curtis or Cole Holderman as alternate entry points on the vacation rental side.
